723552f.text:
Times Square, south from West 47th Street, showing the Times Building, at the intersection of Broadway (left) and Seventh Ave., (right).
About 1905.
New York Edison Co.
NEG ~ 1790

717510f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, north from and including 45th Street.  At the extreme left is a part of the new Hotel Astor. The Astor and Gaiety theaters are shown.

April, 1909

Wurts Brothers.

[handwritten] Slide #149
NEG # 3184 [/handwritten]

717528f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, from, but not including 47th Street, to and including 45th Street. Churchill's Restaurant, owned by a former police lieutenant, is shown at the right. Below it are the Gaiety and Astor theatres, and the Hotel Astor.
April, 1909.

Wurts Brothers.

NEG. # 4849

717503f-a.text:
1532-6 Broadway, at the N.E. corner of West 45th Street, showing the buildings that subsequently were replaced by Lowe's State Theatre. At the right margin appears a portion
of the old New York Theatre.
October 31, 1915
Borough President of Manhattan
No. 943

717507f-a.text:
1538-42 Broadway, adjoining and north of the N.K. corner of West 45th Street.

713213f-a.text:
316 East 45th treet, (Before reconstruction)/ President Borough of Manhattan.
April 20, 1921.

723543f.text:
Broadway, (left) north from West 46th Street, and Seventh Ave., (right) north from the same point, showing a night view of the northern end of the Times Square; the "Great White Way," the worlds greatest
theatrical district.
About 1925.
Ewing Galloway.

713222f-a.text:
45th Street, north side, west from Depew Place. At the right may be seen the beginning of construction work on the New York Central.
October 11,1927.
P. L. Sperr.

723526f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, north from but not including 45th Street. This view also shows Seventh Ave, at the right, north from but not including 45th Street.
About 1930.
Ewing Galloway.

723531f-a.text:
Broadway, south from and including 43rd Street. At the right of this view is Seventh Ave., south from and including 43rd Street.
About 1930.
Ewing Galloway.
Neg. # 2363

713230f-b.text:
West 45th Street, north side, west from (No. 149-157) a point east of Broadway and across same, showing prominently the Lyceum Theatre at No. 149-157; a structure adjoining the rear of Loew's State Theatre which has an entrance on Broadway, through the large office building at the N.E. corner. The edifice partially shown on the left is the Hotel Astor. Westward on 45th Street and between Broadway and Eighth Ave. is the Hotel Piccadilly. This set consists of a negative and a positive view.
September 1935.
W.P.A. Photo.

713230f-a.text:

713232f.text:
West 45th Street, west from a point midway between Broadway and Eighth Ave., and across the latter, showing several of the theatres that line both sides of this street. Shown on the south side is the Booth, the Plymouth and the Golden Theatres. Facing same on the opposite side are the Music Box, Iperial and the C.B.S. (formerly the Avon) Theatres. This set, consisting of three positive and three negative views, shows several different portions of this Times Square theatre district.
November 29, 1935.
W.P.A. Photo.

717514f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, at West 45th Street and southward, showing prominently the Astor Theatre (No. 1531-1537 Broadway) at the N.W. corner of same. Occupying the block fromt southward is the Hotel Astor. The triangular edifice appearing on the left is the Times Building. This area is popularly known as Times Scuare,though the buildings, on both sides bear Broadway addresses. These two views, consisting of a negative
and a positive, comprise a set.
September 1935.
W.P.A. Photo.

714520f-a.text:
W7est 76th Street, west from Broadway, and across West End Ave., to the
North (Hudson) River.
October 29, 1936.
V.P.A. Photo.
Federal Art Proiect.

723547f.text:
Times Square, south from but not including West 46th Street, showing W.P.A. employees removing the Seventh Ave., street car tracks. Broadway (shown on the right) intersects at this point with Seventh Ave. Prominently shown are Loews State Theatre; the Times Building and the Astor Hotel.
July 14, 1936.
W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Art Project.

723546f-b.text:
Times Square, north from West 45th Street, showing the theatrical district of New York. The buildings on both sides of this open area bear Broadway numbers; while north of 47th Street (center, apex), Seventh Ave. regains its identity. This is a set of 2 views, No. 2 of which is
from the Seventh Ave. side.
September 14, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.

723546f-a.text:
Times Square, north from West 45th Street, showing the theatrical district of New York. The buildings on both sides of this open area bear Broadway numbers; while north of 47th Street (center, apex), Seventh Ave. regains its identity. This is a set of 2 views, No. 2 of which is
from the Seventh Ave. side.
September 14, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.

713233f-a.text:
West 45th Street, north side, west from a point midway between Broadway and Eighth Ave. and to the latter, showing three theatres; the Music Box (No. 239); the lmperial (No. 249) and the C.B.S. (No. 25L).
This set consists of a negative and a positive.
1936.
W.P.A. Photo.
Faderal Art Project.

West 45th Street, north side, west from a point midway between Broadway and Eighth Ave. and to the latter, showing three theatres; the Music Box (No. 239); the lmperial (No. 249) and the C.B.S. (No. 25L).

717515f-b.text:
Broadway, west side, from West 45th to 46th Streets, showing prominently the Astor at the N. W. corner. Thts former legitimate theatre is now used for 'ew York premiers of motion pictures. Playing at this date is "Lloyds of London." Above same is the Globe Theatre with a Minsky burlesque attraction. Subse uently the latter actfvtttes were curta'ied by the enforcement of the edioct of the Commissioner of License, sliminating the use Sf the word "burlesque" and the discontinuance of "Strip
Tease" Acts.
1937
Views 1,2
W. P. A.
Federal Writers Project
N. Y. C. Guide
